Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I glance at the clock on my computer screen—ten minutes until the team meeting. As a colleague, I’m expected to be there, to listen and contribute, especially since today’s agenda includes crucial project updates that won’t be shared later. My phone rings, and I recognize the number: Mr. Harris, a long-time customer. I answer, slipping into my telemarketer role, but he’s already upset, his voice sharp as he questions the legitimacy of our latest offer. He demands a detailed explanation, refusing to be brushed off. My heart pounds. I know I can’t rush him; handling objections thoroughly is part of my job, and my supervisor tracks every call. But the meeting is about to start, and my absence will be noticed. I feel the pressure mounting from both sides—my team counting on my presence, my customer demanding my full attention. I grip the phone tighter, torn between the two roles, each pulling me in a different direction, and I can’t see how to satisfy both.
